https://prez.dev/description.@value: A categorization of disciplines or topics that the broad field of Earth science can be subdivided into, i.e. a listing of the Fields of Research, or subjects, to which a geoscience dataset, publication, observation/activity, or entity pertains. The vocabulary also contains relevant disciplines that intersect with the various Earth science fields, such as biological sciences and built environment and design, as well as entries related to collection and heritage management. Notations included are those from the 2020 ANZSRC listing (see History Note) or in common use in the geoscience community.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Climate change science is the study of changes in the statistical properties of the climate system that persists for several decades or longer — usually at least 30 years. In a broader sense, climate change science also includes previous long-term changes to Earth's climate. These statistical properties include averages, variability and extremes. Climate change may be due to natural processes, such as changes in the Sun’s radiation, volcanoes activity or internal variability in the climate system, or due to human influences such as changes in the composition of the atmosphere or land use caused by human activity (e.g. burning of fossil fuels, deforestation). In common usage, climate change is often used interchangeably to describe global warming — the ongoing increase in global average temperature — and its effects on Earth's climate system.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#hist.@value: From the Fields of Research vocabulary from the Australian and New Zealand Standard Research Classification (ANZSRC, 2020). Definition adapted from Wikipedia.

https://prez.dev/description.@value: Climate change science is the study of changes in the statistical properties of the climate system that persists for several decades or longer — usually at least 30 years. In a broader sense, climate change science also includes previous long-term changes to Earth's climate. These statistical properties include averages, variability and extremes. Climate change may be due to natural processes, such as changes in the Sun’s radiation, volcanoes activity or internal variability in the climate system, or due to human influences such as changes in the composition of the atmosphere or land use caused by human activity (e.g. burning of fossil fuels, deforestation). In common usage, climate change is often used interchangeably to describe global warming — the ongoing increase in global average temperature — and its effects on Earth's climate system.

Climatology or climate science is the scientific study of Earth's climate, typically defined as weather conditions averaged over a period of at least 30 years. Climate concerns the atmospheric condition during an extended to indefinite period of time; weather is the condition of the atmosphere during a relative brief period of time and is studied by within the field of meteorology.
